utterance.content: Surgeon found no growths.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Surgeon was trying to put everything back where it was, he wasn’t look…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You may have been lucky. You don’t catch testicular cancer early, it kills. Probably eroded some vessel –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, I know. Question is why I didn’t think of it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Eyes popping out is a rather odd presentation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sac blowing up, on the other hand…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you could think of everything yourself you wouldn’t need a team to annoy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I screwed up some basic anatomy and I’m misconnecting a testicular explosion with a testicular problem. Think there’s any way I would have done that before Cuddy messed with my brain?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She was trying to help you and it worked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I can run like the wind, but I can’t think. Seeing as how I’m too old to become a professional athlete, she screwed me over, big time.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You don’t want a healthy leg.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, here we go.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you’ve got a good life, you’re healthy, you’ve got no reason to bitch, no reason to hate life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, here’s the flaw in your argument: if I enjoy hating life, I don’t hate life, I enjoy it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I didn’t say it was rational. HIV testing is ninety-nine percent accurate, which means there are some people who test positive, who live with their own impending doom for months or years before finding out everything’s okay. Weirdly, most of them don’t react with happiness, or even anger. They get depressed, not because they wanted to die, but because they’ve defined themselves by their disease. Suddenly, what made them ‘them’ isn’t real.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t define myself by my leg.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you have taken it one step further. The only way you could come to terms with your disability was to some way make it mean nothing. So you had to redefine everything. You have dismissed anything physical, anything not coldly, calculatingly intellectual.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you protecting her?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because she’s done nothing wrong?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re completely comfortable with what she did to me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, I am. Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You agonize over moral choices. You aren’t completely comfortable with anything until you’ve taken days to get your head around every possible side. I’ve known what she did for six hours. How come you’re acting like you’ve known for days?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do I have?!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not sick –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do I have?!?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You need to calm down –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have my brain. That’s it!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We were trying to help you!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, nobody tries to screw up, they just do!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You were out of control, you were shooting morphine –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can make people better! And you decide to trade that for jogging shoes!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you’re suffering from side effects then we can look at that and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You value the physical so much, let me put this in terms you understand!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re unbelievable. Even when you’re out of your mind with anger and fear, you still couch it in logical terms. Are you hallucinating?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I’m hallucinating!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, I mean right now. Are you hallucinating?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How did you know I was –

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You were yelling at me. You were calling me Wilson.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You’re losing it, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I never called Wilson by his name.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, right. The hallucinator is going to tell the hallucinatee what happened.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re not the hallucinatee, Wilson was the hallucinatee.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You think maybe you’re focusing on the wrong thing here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy’s office was the hallucinatee, the bathroom was the hallucinatee.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: Ah. Bathroom. It figures.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What figures?

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You wet your bed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Test was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Efp and beta HGG say no testicular cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, let’s recap. We’ve just ruled out everything, which doesn’t make sense, and the answer has to be something that does make sense. Do a cystoscopy, make sure he’s human.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Test was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For him being human?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Everything was right where it was supposed to be, all the tubes go where they’re supposed to go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Most likely scenario is some kind of bacterial prostatitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm. Find out if his father hunched? His father have trouble peeing? His father have sex with his own mother? The answer to any of these questions, if yes, assume you’re right. If the answer’s no, assume you’re right, but biopsy some prostate lymphs just to make sure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But then we’d have to cut through his stomach, and since he’s clearly got a bleeding problem, this kind of surgery might –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t clearly have anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How did I get here?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was in the ICU, and then I was coming down these stairs with you guys. What happened in between? I don’t remember how I got here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m taking myself off my case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your patient’s in critical care, he’s had a fever unabated for two –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think I’m losing my mind. I’m having blackouts.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You said you weren’t having any –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I lied.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you are doing this to scare me, you made your point. Next time you get shot, I promise to only treat the bullet wounds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m off the case. Why did you jump up when I came in?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I thought you were going to attack me again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Again?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, you were in my face. You were –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I wasn’t.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You came in here with Wilson and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That was a hallucination –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, you –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: -- which means this is a hallucination.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How can I tell what’s real and what’s not? Everything looks the same, sounds the same, tastes the same.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: Seems like I’d be the last person you’d want to ask.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why not? You’re obviously not here. I’m obviously not here, which means this is a creation of my mind, which means I’m really just asking my mind.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You’re talking to yourself, there’s a lot of unnecessary explanation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, I’m trying to work this out. That requires give and take, even in my own mind.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: All right, what was the question?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How can I tell what’s real?

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: Does it matter?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That doesn’t sound like something I’d ask.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: All right, your concern is that if you act in the real world based on information that’s not real, the results are impossible to foresee.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: With you so far.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: But information is incapable of harm in and of itself. Ideas are neither good nor bad, but merely as useful as what we do with it. Only actions can cause harm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That sounds like me.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: So you do nothing, you refrain from taking any actions. Continue to throw out your ideas as you always would, but if they’re based on faulty assumptions your team will point that out. They won’t do anything that could hurt him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So I trust my team.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Test was negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No blood in the prostate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No structural abnormalities.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Something doesn’t make sense. What does that mean? It’s not rhetorical. I need your input on everything I ask, no matter how obvious it might seem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It means you’re wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means one of your assumptions is wrong, because if something doesn’t make sense it can’t be real. So what are our assumptions?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We don’t have any, we’re just guessing and testing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We assume the tests are right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ve already redone them, twice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let’s go more basic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s more basic than the test results?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tests themselves. What does a biopsy consist of?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You take a sample –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Define sample.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s a small, representative piece of whatever you think is the problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You go down the shore, you fill a cup with water. It’s got no fish in it. Does that mean no fish in the ocean?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We can do another biopsy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We can fill another cup of water, but we’ve gotta dive in. We’ve gotta see what’s actually in there.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We can’t operate, he’s got a bleeding problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We assume he’s got a bleeding problem.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, because he bled from where he wasn’t supposed to bleed, causing parts of his body to blow up! Assuming that crazy assumption is correct, we operate on him, we’ll kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if we could find a way of doing the surgery without giving him more than a papercut?

utterance.speaker: Vince
utterance.content: You want to let a robot operate on me?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The technology is amazing. It magnifies everything ten times, it’s ten times the accuracy.

utterance.speaker: Vince
utterance.content: No way, I want a person!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A person will be controlling the –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People suck. People have turned you from a guy with a swollen tongue into a guy with one guy, one ball and a stapled-on face. If you want someone to hold you while you cry yourself to sleep at night, choose warm and soft. If you want someone to write you a poem, pick the sensitive loner. If all you care about is that something’s done right, pick the guy with the metal head.

utterance.speaker: Vince
utterance.content: No way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No way no way. You’ve gotta see this thing in action before you say “no way.” Come on.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing. I’m not doing anything. Just throwing out ideas. I think you should put him in a wheelchair and take him down to the OR, but I may be out of my mind.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax, Cameron. I’m not going to cut you. I just want to show what this puppy can do. I can make one millimeter incisions. You know how small that is? Small even in metric. If I do something that doesn’t make sense, even to you, stop me. Delicate, no? [He then lifts up the hem of her shirt and uses the air hand to blow air into her belly button. And then he cuts off a button on her blouse, peeling part of the shirt away to reveal her bra.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does that hurt. Seen enough?

utterance.speaker: Vince
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That wasn’t a question. You either do this, or you die.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You’ve wasted your life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. If only I’d dedicated my life to finding someone worthy to shoot.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: If I’d’ve killed you, would it have mattered?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not to me.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: You don’t care whether you live or die?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I care because I live. I can’t care if I’m dead.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: I don’t want to hear semantics.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You anti-semantic bastard.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: Would anybody care that the world lost that wit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Working, here.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: That’s all right, you don’t have to say anything. Just let me soak into your subconscious. You think that the only truth that matters is the truth that can be measured. Good intentions don’t count, what’s in your heart doesn’t count, caring doesn’t count, that a man’s life can’t be measured by how many tears are shed when he dies. It’s because you can’t measure them. It’s because you don’t want to measure them. Doesn’t mean it’s not real.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That does not make sense.

utterance.speaker: Jack
utterance.content: And even if I’m wrong, you’re still miserable. Did you really think that your life’s purpose was to sacrifice yourself and get nothing in return? No. You believe there is no purpose to anything. Even the lives you save you dismiss. You turn the one decent thing in your life and you taint it, strip it of all meaning. You’re miserable for nothing. I don’t know why you’d want to live.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I know what’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, get out of here! You’re not sterile!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Great. What’s he got?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How come you guys have never tried to yank me off this case? I’m having hallucinations, blackouts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But you’re always insane, and you’re always right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m almost always eventually right. You have no way of knowing when ‘eventually’ is. Every time I’ve had an epiphany on this one you guys were right on board. No challenges, nothing to explain. No offense, but either you guys are getting smarter or I’m getting dumber.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ve worked with you long enough to know –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know the test results even before you enter the room. We have identical knowledge. How is that possible?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Something doesn’t make sense. One of your assumptions has to be wrong, because if something doesn’t make sense then it can’t be real. But what if the faulty assumption is that it’s real?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, you’re losing it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve lost it. Why did you stop me?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because I think you’re going to kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t think that. You know it, because you’re in my head. As long as the delusion makes sense my mind lets it go on. To make it not make sense I have to push it past the point where it can trick my mind.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, hey! This is a nightmare, you’re gonna wake up. It’s real, you’re killing a man!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s also possible I may already be dead, but I don’t believe in the afterlife.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House, go back to your room. If this is a hallucination, it’s a good one: you’re pain free, you can walk –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is not real, therefore it’s meaningless. I want meaning. Oh, God. Goodbye.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He was shot!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Twice!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Once in the abdomen, once in the neck.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s going to be okay. You’re going to be okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t know that. Tell Cuddy I want ketamine.
